title: Understanding the Problem
text: To determine which color of visible light can eject electrons from the metal, we need to compare the energy of the light with the threshold frequency of the metal. The threshold frequency is the minimum frequency needed to eject electrons.

title: Relating Frequency and Wavelength
text: The formula $$𝑐=𝜆𝜈$$ relates the speed of light (c), wavelength (𝜆), and frequency (𝜈). This formula helps us find the wavelength of light that corresponds to the threshold frequency.

title: Calculating Wavelength
text: Rearrange the formula $$𝑐=𝜆𝜈$$ to solve for wavelength: $$𝜆=\frac{c}{ν}$$. Use the given threshold frequency 5.45×10**14 $$s^{-1}$$ and the speed of light 2.998×10**8 $$\frac{m}{s}$$ to find the wavelength.

title: Converting Wavelength to Nanometers
text: Once you have the wavelength in meters, convert it to nanometers by using the conversion factor 1nm=1×10**-9m.

title: Identifying the Color
text: Compare the calculated wavelength in nanometers to the typical wavelength ranges for colors of visible light. This will help you identify which color corresponds to the calculated wavelength.

title: Final Answer
text: Based on the wavelength you calculated, which color of visible light has enough energy to eject electrons from the metal?
